question_text: Can CC prove NEW NC lower bounds?
answer: YES - CC proves width, depth, and combined 2D lower bounds for NC

main_theorem.name: CC Lower Bound Theorem
main_theorem.statement: Coordination complexity techniques prove new NC lower bounds via coordination capacity (width), coordination rounds (depth), and combined 2D grid analysis
main_theorem.interpretation: CC provides a COMPLETE framework for NC lower bounds

MATRIX-MULT.problem: Multiply two n x n matrices
MATRIX-MULT.cc_analysis: Requires coordination capacity n^2 (all partial products)
MATRIX-MULT.novelty: Previously known via counting, now provable via CC

MATRIX-INVERSE.problem: Invert an n x n matrix
MATRIX-INVERSE.novelty: NEW: Coordination analysis gives cleaner proof

ITERATED-MATRIX-POWER.problem: Compute A^m for n x n matrix A
ITERATED-MATRIX-POWER.novelty: Coordination rounds directly map to depth

TRANSITIVE-CLOSURE.problem: Compute transitive closure of a graph
TRANSITIVE-CLOSURE.novelty: Classic result, now via CC framework

NC2-COMPLETE.cc_analysis: Requires (log^2 depth, poly width) position on grid
NC2-COMPLETE.lower_bound: DEPTH >= Omega(log^2 n) AND WIDTH >= Omega(n^c) for some c
NC2-COMPLETE.novelty: NEW: 2D lower bound from single CC analysis

WIDTH-NC2-nk-COMPLETE.lower_bound: DEPTH >= Omega(log^2 n) AND WIDTH >= Omega(n^k)

technique.name: CC Lower Bound Technique

steps.action: Analyze coordination structure of problem P
steps.details: Determine how P requires information to be combined across distributed agents
How many sequential communication rounds are needed?
How much state must be tracked simultaneously?
Position (i, k) means depth log^i n, width n^k
The hierarchy is STRICT, so the bound is tight

technique.example_application:
EXAMPLE: Proving lower bound for 3-TENSOR-CONTRACT

Step 1: 3-tensor contraction requires combining n^3 values
Step 2: Can be done in O(log^2 n) rounds (matrix-like operations)
Step 3: Requires capacity n^3 (all tensor entries)
Step 4: Position on grid: (2, 3) = (NC^2 depth, width n^3)
Step 5: By Phase 76: WIDTH-NC^2(n^3) is strict level

RESULT: 3-TENSOR-CONTRACT requires:
- Depth >= Omega(log^2 n)
- Width >= Omega(n^3)

This is a NEW 2D lower bound proven via CC!

counting.limitations: Only proves existence bounds, not structure

restriction.technique: Restrict circuit class, prove lower bound there
restriction.strengths: Can prove strong bounds for restricted classes
restriction.limitations: May not extend to general circuits

communication.technique: Use communication complexity to bound depth

strengths: Provides BOTH depth AND width bounds simultaneously
Connects circuit complexity to distributed computing
limitations: P vs NP remains challenging (different structure)

comparison_to_traditional.key_advantage:
CC UNIQUE ADVANTAGE: The 2D Grid

Traditional methods prove:
- Depth lower bounds (communication complexity)
- Size lower bounds (counting)
- Width lower bounds (rare, ad hoc)

CC approach proves ALL THREE via unified framework:
- Coordination rounds -> depth
- Coordination capacity -> width
- Combined analysis -> 2D position

The 2D grid from Phase 77 is a NEW TOOL for circuit lower bounds!

for_circuit_complexity.insight: CC provides a COMPLETE framework for NC lower bounds
for_circuit_complexity.impact: No longer need ad hoc arguments for each problem
for_circuit_complexity.future: Systematic approach to classifying NC problems

for_parallel_computing.insight: Lower bounds reveal fundamental parallelization limits
for_parallel_computing.impact: Know when algorithms CANNOT be improved

for_p_vs_np.insight: CC succeeds for NC but challenges remain for NP
for_p_vs_np.observation: NP doesn't fit the 2D grid cleanly
for_p_vs_np.direction: Need to understand why NP is structurally different

for_lower_bounds_generally.insight: 2D grid is a NEW lower bound tool
for_lower_bounds_generally.potential: May extend beyond NC to other classes

new_questions.question: Can CC lower bounds extend beyond NC to P?
What is the tightest CC lower bound provable for specific problems?
Can CC lower bounds prove P != NC?
Do CC lower bounds bypass natural proofs barriers?
Can CC techniques prove SIZE lower bounds (not just depth/width)?

key_insights: Coordination capacity maps to circuit WIDTH
Coordination rounds map to circuit DEPTH
The 2D NC grid enables COMBINED lower bounds
CC provides a systematic framework (not ad hoc)
This is a NEW lower bound technique for circuit complexity
